spans.content: Atomic Layer Deposition of Hafnium Dioxide Films from Hafnium Tetrakis(ethylmethylamide) and Water**

Keywords: Atomic layer deposition, Dielectrics, Hafnium dioxide, Ion beam analysis

is a potential candidate for several applications such as high- permittivity dielectric oxide in metal oxide semiconductor (MOS) devices[1- 3] thin film capacitors,[4] gas- sensing devices,[5] tunnel junctions,[6] and laser damage- resistant optical coatings.[7] The maximum dielectric constant value for

, have been the common Hf precursors in the ALD process. In ALD, a substrate surface is alternately exposed to highly reactive metal and oxygen precursors, and the solid film forms as a result of successive surface reactions between (sub)monolayers of precursor molecules alternately adsorbed.
have been applied to grow binary
have also been applied in an ALD process.[24] The permittivity of the
.[11] Gordon et al.[25] have noted that it is possible to grow
films in ALD mode from hafnium tetrakis(dimethylamide), and
per cycle. However, the properties of these films were not described. It is to be noted that the reproducibility of
may sometimes suffer from particle transport, originating from the hafnium precursor,[11] therefore the exploitation of liquid precursors, ensuring uniform precursor delivery, is recommended.
films were grown by ALD from a novel hafnium precursor, hafnium tetrakis(ethylmethylamide), and

in order to investigate the basic features of the film growth in this new precursor combination. The dependence of the growth rate on the substrate temperature and ALD cycle time parameters was investigated. In addition, the effect of substrate temperature on the film structure and composition will be described. Preliminary results on the dielectric properties of the films grown at various temperatures will be reported.

A separate experiment was carried out to examine the thermal decomposition of the hafnium precursor.
was pulsed 1500- 2750 times with a pulse length of
and without an intermittent hydrolysis step, i.e., a water pulse. At

, ultrathin, brownish layers of unknown composition were formed on the glass substrates, indicating weak thermal decomposition. Thus, the growth cannot be expected to be perfectly self- limiting. The increase in growth rate at lower temperatures may be due to the increased density of functional adsorption sites
groups) or the molecular adsorption of the precursor. At higher temperatures, the growth rate can be enhanced by intense thermal decomposition of the hafnium precursor.

measured in this study, agrees with the literature values.[7,9,13- 15] From Figure 3, it can be seen that the maximum values of refractive index coincide with the region of temperature- independent growth rate, whereas too low or too high temperatures are likely to result in films of reduced density or changed composition, as well as decreased refractive index. It is still important to mention that the changes in refractive index values are really small, therefore no substantial changes in film quality are expected over the whole temperature range studied.
Figures 4 and 5 demonstrate selected X- ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the

films deposited at varying temperatures on glass and silicon substrates, respectively. Because the intensity of the diffraction peaks is generally higher, it can be seen that the films grown at relatively high temperatures are more crystalline. Otherwise, no particular differences between the phase contents of the films grown on both types of substrate were observed. In the films grown on ITO, the dominant peaks belonged to the 111 and 111 reflections of the monoclinic phase[27] (not shown), whereas on Si substrates, the most intense reflections (such as 020 and 200), were essentially weaker in the films grown on ITO. The monoclinic
phase was predominant in all the films, except those grown below

where the temperature was obviously too low to initiate noticeable crystallization (Fig. 4). In the films grown on silicon, trace reflections from tetragonal or orthorhombic phases were also detected at a
value of 30.41 (Fig. 5). This is characteristic of ALD
since similar minor reflections from metastable phases were also seen in the films grown from

respectively. The respective film thicknesses were

.This is an interesting result because the roughness actually decreased with the increase in the deposition temperature, although, simultaneously, the crystallinity increased with the growth temperature (Fig.5).From the AFM images of the samples grown at
in Figure 6,it can be seen that
the grain size decreases considerably with the growth temperature, resulting in reduced roughness. This may be due to the increased nucleation density at
. At the same time, neither crystal size (possibly increasing with temperature and larger in the film bulk), nor film thickness affected the surface smoothness.

Figure 7 depicts the concentrations of residual impurities in the
films as a function of growth temperature. In the films grown below
, carbon and nitrogen levels remained in the ranges
films grown onto Si(100) at a)
Fig. 7. Concentrations of hydrogen, carbon, and nitrogen residues versus growth temperature. Lines are guides for the eye.
respectively, whereas a slight increase in the contamination level occurred at higher deposition temperatures. The hydrogen content in the films grown in the temperature range

whereas increased amounts of hydrogen were found in the films grown at both lower and higher temperatures. Generally, the contaminants were distributed homogeneously throughout the film thickness. In some samples, a hydrogen peak was detected at the film surface, possibly coming from adsorbed water. Zirconium was also found in all of the
films in concentrations not exceeding 0.2- 0.4 at.
Zirconium is the common impurity in hafnium- based compounds and hafnium precursors.
For comparison, Ohshita et al.[19] obtained sub- stoichiometric oxides from

at lower temperatures than so far reported for alkylamide- based CVD.
Some capacitor structures were fabricated in order to verify the dielectric behavior of
films grown in this study. Figure 8 demonstrates capacitance- voltage
on HF- etched Si, and at
on a Si substrate with a ca.
, respectively, and the films were not heat treated before measurements. All the
curves demonstrated counterclockwise hysteresis when swept from positive to negative bias forward, and from negative to positive bias backwards.
The flat- band voltage in typical

curves exhibited a shift in flat- band voltage towards positive bias (Fig. 8) during the forward sweep. This is due to the intense injection of negative charge from the substrate under positive bias. The hysteresis width is noticeably larger in the films grown at lower temperature. This may be due to the (assumed to be) thinner
interface layer, but perhaps also to the more homogeneous nature (i.e., crystalline phase dominating
growth temperatures. The thickness of the films grown at
over an amorphous phase) of the film grown at

. The hysteresis width can be estimated using the difference between dissipation maxima occurring near flat- band conditions. The density of the oxide rechargeable traps may then be calculated from the hysteresis width.[28] For the
curves depicted in Figure 8, one obtains the oxide trap densities

respectively. The difference in the breakdown resistance in the films grown at higher temperature can be explained by somewhat higher polycrystallinity and some contribution from the grain boundary conductivity. In the
and this can give rise to breakdown resistance. In these particular samples, the pre- breakdown leakage current was between

, the pre- breakdown current remained between

. More detailed study on the dielectric properties is beyond the scope of the present paper. Possible formation and effect of interface layers on HF- etched Si, as well as its increase during deposition and storage in ambient air, remains a matter for future investigation. Further, the effect of growth and annealing temperatures, film thickness, and structure on the permittivity and interface quality should also be studied.

The films were grown in a hot- wall horizontal flow- type ALD reactor [29] onto borosilicate glass, Si(100), and glass substrates covered by patterned ITO electrodes. The substrate temperature was varied in the range
. The pressure in the reactor was about
product number 553 123) was evaporated from an open boat at
vapor was generated in an external reservoir at room temperature and led into the reactor through needle and solenoid valves. Metal precursor pulse length was varied between
, while the water pulse length was held at

were used after each precursor pulse to separate the precursor flows in the gas phase and to remove the excess reactants and gaseous reaction by- products from the system. Nitrogen was used as both precursor carrier and purge gas.

The film thickness and optical properties were calculated from optical transmission spectra [31] measured by a Hitachi U- 2000 spectrophotometer. The structure of the films was determined by means of a Philips MPD 1880 powder X- ray diffractometer using

radiation and the Bragg- Brentano geometry. The surface roughness of some selected samples was evaluated using a ThermoMicroscopes CP Research AFM. The film composition and residual contamination level were evaluated by TOF- ERDA [32]. A
beam for TOF- ERDA was obtained from a
tandem accelerator EGP- 10- II, and forward scattered iodine ions and recoiled target atoms were used for the determination of
and lighter elements, respectively. Dielectric properties were measured after e- beam evaporation of aluminum electrodes with an effective electrode area of
. After film deposition, the reverse of the silicon substrates were etched in hydrofluoric acid and metallized by evaporating a
thick Al layer. Thus, the electrical measurements were carried out on
curves were recorded using a HP 4284a, precision LCR meter. The stair- sweep voltage step was
, and the period between voltage steps was
voltage applied to the capacitor was
while the frequency of the AC signal was held at either
. The current- voltage curves were measured with a Keithley 2400 Source Meter in the stair- sweep voltage mode, while the voltage step used was
. All measurements were carried out at room temperature.
